Short answer questions: correct answers are worth full points in this problem. (a) [5] Let α, β be complex numbers. Determine the generating function for the sequence (an)∞ n=0 deﬁned by a0 = α, a1 = β, and an = an−1 + an−2, n ≥ 2. Solution: Let A(x) = ∑n≥0 anxn be the generating function. Then A(x) = ∑ n≥0 anxn = α + βx + ∑ n≥2 anxn = α + βx + ∑ n≥2 an−1xn + ∑ n≥2 an−2xn = α + βx + x(A(x) − α) + x2A(x). Solving for A(x) gives A(x) = α + (β − α)x 1 − x − x2 . (b) [5] Determine the generating function for the sequence (bn)∞ n=0 deﬁned by b0 = 0, and bn = 2bn−1 + n for n ≥ 1. Solution: Let B(x) = ∑ n≥0 bnxn be the generating function. Then B(x) = ∑ n≥0 bnxn = ∑ n≥1 bnxn = ∑ n≥1 2bn−1xn + ∑ n≥1 nxn = 2xB(x) + x (1 − x)2 . Solving for B(x) gives B(x) = x (1 − x)2(1 − 2x) . 2. [10] Let n be a positive integer. Show that the number of partitions of n into odd parts greater than 1 is equal to the number of partitions of n into unequal parts none of which is a power of two. Solution: Let an denote the number of partitions of n into odd parts greater than 1. The generating function for (an) is A(x) = 1 (1 − x3)(1 − x5)(1 − x7) · · · . Also, let bn denote the number of partitions of n into unequal parts none of which is a power of two. The generating function for (bn) is B(x) = (1 + x)(1 + x2)(1 + x3)(1 + x4) · · · (1 + x)(1 + x2)(1 + x4)(1 + x8) · · · . Note that we have (1 + x)(1 + x 2)(1 + x4)(1 + x8) · · · = (1 − x2)(1 − x4)(1 − x8) · · · (1 − x)(1 − x2)(1 − x4) · · · = 1 1 − x , 11 AwesomeMath 2007 Track 1 — Combinatorics Week 3 and (1 + x)(1 + x2)(1 + x3)(1 + x4) · · · = (1 − x2)(1 − x4)(1 − x6) · · · (1 − x)(1 − x2)(1 − x3) · · · = 1 (1 − x)(1 − x3)(1 − x5)(1 − x7) · · · . Combining the two, we ﬁnd that A(x) = B(x). Therefore, an = bn for all n, as desired. 3. [10] Seven students take a mathematical exam. Every problem was solved by at most 3 students. For every pair of students, there is at least one problem that they both solved. Determine, with proof, the minimum number of problems on this exam. Solution: Assume that there are n problems. Let T denote the number of pairs (P, S), where P is a problem, and S is a pair of students who both solved P . On one hand, since every problem was solved at at most 3 students, we have T ≤ (3 2 )n = 3n. On the other hand, since there is such a pair (P, S) for every pair of students, we have T ≥ (7 2 ) = 21. Thus, 3n ≥ 21, so n ≥ 7. Let us show that n = 7 can be attained. Label the problems 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and the let each of the following set denote the set of problems that an individual a student has solved: {1, 2, 3}, {1, 4, 7}, {1, 5, 6}, {2, 5, 7}, {2, 4, 6}, {3, 4, 5}, {3, 6, 7}. Therefore, the minimum number of problems on this exam is 7. Remarks: Although the construction can be found by trial and error, it can be motivated by the Fano plane, which is depicted below. Each vertex represents a problem, and each line (including the center circle) represents a student who solved the problems that the line passes through. 1 2 345 6 7 4. [10] Find the number of subsets of {1, 2, . . . , 2007} (including the empty set) the sum of whose elements is divisible by 17. Solution: Consider the polynomial f (x) = (1 + x)(1 + x 2)(1 + x3) · · · (1 + x2007). Every subset {a1, a2, . . . , ak} ⊂ {1, 2, . . . , 2007} corresponds to a term in the expansion of f (x), namely xa1+a2+···+ak . Therefore, for each m, the coeﬃcient of xm is f (x) equals to the number of subsets of {1, 2, . . . , 2007} the sum of whose elements is m. Therefore, we need the 12 AwesomeMath 2007 Track 1 — Combinatorics Week 3 ﬁnd the sum of the coeﬃcients of x0, x17, x34, . . . , x2006. This can be done using the roots of unity. Let ζ = e2πi/17. Then, the answer equals to 1 17 (f (1) + f (ζ) + f (ζ 2) + · · · + f (ζ 16)) . We must evaluate this expression. First, notice that since the zeros of x17 − 1 are 1, ζ, ζ 2, . . . , ζ 16, so x17 − 1 = (x − 1)(x − ζ)(x − ζ 2) · · · (x − ζ 16). Setting x = −1 yields the identity (1 + 1)(1 + ζ)(1 + ζ 2) · · · (1 + ζ 16) = 2. Note that for 1 ≤ k ≤ 16, {0, k, 2k, 3k, . . . , 16k} is a permutation of {0, 1, 2, 3, . . . , 16} as residues in mod 17. It follows that (1 + 1)(1 + ζ k)(1 + ζ 2k) · · · (1 + ζ 16k) = 2. Consequently, since 2007 = 17 · 118 + 1, we have f (ζ k) = (1 + ζ k)(1 + ζ 2k) · · · (1 + ζ 2007k) = [(1 + 1)(1 + ζ k)(1 + ζ 2k) · · · (1 + ζ 16k) ]118 (1 + ζ k) = 2 118(1 + ζ k). Also, f (1) = 22007. Therefore, 1 17 (f (1) + f (ζ) + f (ζ 2) + · · · + f (ζ 16) ) = 1 17 (2 2007 + 2118(16 + ζ + ζ 2 + ζ 3 + · · · + ζ 16)) = 1 17 2118 (2 1889 + 15) . Thus, the answer is 2118(21889+15) 17 . 13
